Coronaviruses belong to the family of Coronaviridae. Bats have been recognized as natural reservoir and vectors of a variety of coronaviruses and the viruses have crossed species barriers to infect humans and many other different kinds of animals, including avians, rodents, and chiropters.
50 ,
51 Coronavirus may cause respiratory and neurological diseases.
52 So far, six human coronaviruses (HCoVs) have been identified, including HCoV‐229E, HCoV‐HKU1, HCoV‐OC43, HCoV‐NL63, severe acute respiratory syndrome coronavirus (SARS‐CoV), and Middle East respiratory syndrome coronavirus (MERS‐CoV).
53 MERS‐CoV is a human coronavirus first reported in June 2012 that can cause human respiratory diseases.
52 It has been classified as a lineage C β‐coronavirus, and its structure comprises a ~30 kb positive‐sense, single‐stranded RNA genome, which is closely related to the lineage C β‐coronaviruses of Tylonycteris bat CoV HKU4 and Pipistrellus bat CoV HKU5.
54 By genomic analysis of lineage C β‐coronaviruses, human MERS‐CoV has shown high similarities to MERS‐CoV derived from camels with >99.5% nucleotide identities, suggesting that the human and camel isolates belong to the same coronavirus species.
4 As of September 30, 2019, 2468 laboratory‐confirmed cases of MERS‐CoV infections, including 851 deaths in 27 countries, have been reported to WHO ( https://www.who.int/emergencies/mers-cov/en/). Because no commercial vaccines or therapeutic treatments are currently available for MERS, rapid and accurate diagnosis of MERS‐CoV is important for the prevention of its transmission and outbreaks.
